content: larger crochet hook practice keeping your stitch loops loose enough to match the size of the crochet hook neither too tight nor too loose pattern notes i ve learned that many crocheters forget what they ve read here in this pattern notes section once they start crocheting this is why i now add tips and notes between some of the row of the pattern tip i ve set apart tips from the rest of the pattern by indenting them and using a different font like you see here each rib is created with two row of bloslst the ribbed fabric is just like corrugated cardboard a raised rib on one side is the deep valley between ribs on the other side both sides look the same if you don t change to a strongly contrasting color each complete group of short row row 1 - 16 creates a wedge shape if you have questions or comments please contact me vashtibraha@gmail com click here to see a helpful image bank for this design o\ begin slip slope scarf g g make a slip knot and place on crochet hook chain 25 row 1 right side of first wedge slip_stitch in the bottom third loop or bump of the 2nd chain from hook and mark place a st marker in it slip_stitch in the bump loop of each remaining chain chain 1 turn 24 sl sts note if you are new to slip_stitch crochet please start out using stitch markers to mark the first stitch of each new row i used to think they were annoying and avoided using them now i m kinder to myself after a little while you won t need them and can stop using them row 2 slip_stitch in the blo of first slip_stitch mark it slip_stitch in blo of each of the next 20 sl sts chain 1 turn leaving remaining 3 sl sts unworked 21 sl sts © 2011 by vashti braha all rights reserved licensing inquiries vashtibraha@gmail com thank you for your support of independent crochet designers & publishers \ a designingvashti crochet project slip slope scarf page 5 of 6 tip turn the same direction each time you come to the end of a row to result in the neatest finished edge and to help make the last stitch of each row easier to recognize i like to turn as if turning the page of a book so that the yarn ends up behind the turning chain row 1 -
